text:
Fascinating video that popped up on my radar today of Stephen Wolfram demoing Mathematica in 1989 <https://youtu.be/MeuCAT5HDh0?si=mZHZtW1YmDmH4aRT|https://youtu.be/MeuCAT5HDh0?si=mZHZtW1YmDmH4aRT>

I was quite blown away by how powerful and ahead of its time it was, even back then, with features like interactive programming in a very high level, multi-paradigm language for symbolic computation with rich, introspectable outputs and various thoughtful design decisions around interoperability, extensibility and API (as validated by how none of the API functions demo'd have changed AFAIK in 30+ years!)

attachments.video_html: <iframe width="400" height="300" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/MeuCAT5HDh0?feature=oembed&autoplay=1&iv_load_policy=3" frameborder="0" allow="accelerometer; autoplay; clipboard-write; encrypted-media; gyroscope; picture-in-picture; web-share" allowfullscreen title="Introducing Mathematica, Stephen Wolfram"></iframe>
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: Introducing Mathematica, Stephen Wolfram
attachments.title: Introducing Mathematica, Stephen Wolfram

elements.text: Fascinating video that popped up on my radar today of Stephen Wolfram demoing Mathematica in 1989

I was quite blown away by how powerful and ahead of its time it was, even back then, with features like interactive programming in a very high level, multi-paradigm language for symbolic computation with rich, introspectable outputs and various thoughtful design decisions around interoperability, extensibility and API (as validated by how none of the API functions demo'd have changed AFAIK in 30+ years!)
